The plot revolves around Bartleby, who creates a fake college to avoid disappointing his parents, leading to comedic situations as other "accepted" students show up. The humor is lighthearted, and the film also touches on themes of education and self-determination, making it both fun and thought-provoking.

reviews.review1: This review expresses disappointment with *Stigmata*, criticizing its reliance on Roman Catholic mythology which the reviewer found uninteresting. The plot, particularly the depiction of stigmata on an atheist character, felt implausible and the repetitive, gory scenes became tiresome rather than scary. Overall, the reviewer found the movie neither frightening nor enjoyable.

Movie Review: The reviewer was disappointed with the film, noting that it failed to capture the improvisational and goofy nature of Barenaked Ladies' live performances, which they find to be the most interesting aspect of the band. While they acknowledge the concert footage is decent, the shooting is lackluster, and the interviews seem rather dull. Overall, the documentary comes off as lifeless, offering little in the way of new information, since the band's rise to fame is not explored in depth.

Movie Review: The reviewer criticizes the film for inaccurately portraying Charles Darwin’s life and personality, suggesting that it dramatizes Darwin’s struggles and emotions, ultimately undermining his scientific accomplishments. The reviewer expresses dissatisfaction with how the film sensationalizes Darwin's personal conflicts rather than focusing on his intellectual rigor, stating that it falls short in depicting scientific inquiry. They do not recommend the film.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: The reviewer found *Creation* to be a remarkable and joyful cinematic experience, contrary to other reviews that called it 'disappointing.' The film explores Charles Darwin's personal struggles with faith, family, and truth, portraying the emotional and intellectual toll of his scientific discoveries. The reviewer praises the performances of the cast, particularly Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly, and highlights how the film profoundly captures the conflict between science and religion during Darwin's time.

reviews.review1: The reviewer found *Hoot* to be a terrific and heartwarming film with adorable owls and a simple, yet important, message about caring for the environment. They appreciated how the film brought attention to an environmental issue and sparked a meaningful conversation with their children. The combination of fun characters, animals, and a valuable lesson made it a great, entertaining, and educational experience for the whole family.

The reviewer expresses strong disappointment with "Jurassic Park III," criticizing its lack of continuity and sensibility compared to the previous films. They specifically take issue with the introduction of the Spinosaurus and other plot points, like the raptors evolving advanced communication and the unrealistic incidents involving the T-Rex. Overall, the reviewer feels the movie fails to honor the legacy of the original and advises audiences to avoid it.

Movie Review: This gritty, hard-hitting crime thriller follows a tough team of rogue New York cops led by Buddy Manucci, expertly portrayed by Roy Scheider, as they pursue violent mobsters involved in a kidnapping ring. With potent direction from Philip D'Antoni, action-packed sequences, and chilling moral ambiguity between law enforcers and criminals, the film presents a raw and realistic view of urban crime. The film's intense car chase and climactic shootout are particularly memorable highlights.

Movie Review: The reviewer reflects on "Fire Over England", primarily appreciating Flora Robson's performance yet finding the film challenging to follow. They question some historical choices in the script and felt disconnected from the story, especially with unclear romantic interests and a preference for more daylight scenes in the cinematography. While Flora Robson's role was memorable, the film overall didn't match the engagement offered by others like Bette Davis's works.

This movie is extremely funny, especially because of the hilarious character of momma with her dry and witty lines, like telling her son to bury his friend or suspecting him of trying to kill her with unsalted nuts. Fans of movies like National Lampoon's Vacation or Uncle Buck will enjoy this wholesome and humorous film, making it a must-see!

David Suchet delivers an outstanding performance as a meticulous and detail-oriented detective, portraying perfection in everything he does. His attention to the smallest behavior in suspects, along with breathtaking visuals of the English countryside, captivates the audience. Megan Dodds also shines in her role, keeping crucial secrets from Poirot, making the film a very enjoyable watch for fans of Suchet’s portrayal of the famous detective.

movie_metadata.title: They Died with Their Boots On
movie_metadata.matched_title: They Died with Their Boots On (1941)

reviews.movie: They Died with Their Boots On
reviews.review1: Movie Review: This movie, released by Warner Brothers before WWII, is a fictionalized and semi-heroic portrayal of General Custer’s life. Though it lacks historical accuracy, the film acknowledges its creative liberties and focuses on action, style, and character relationships. With great performances by Errol Flynn and Olivia DeHavilland, especially in their eighth and final pairing, and excellent action sequences by director Raoul Walsh, the film succeeds as an entertaining adventure.

The reviewer highlights the strong influence of the movie on the game Grand Theft Auto: Vice City, noting that several elements of the game were inspired by the film. They praise the movie as one of the best from the 1980s and highly recommend it, giving it a 10/10 rating.

Movie Review: This film follows a group of saboteurs trying to undermine the American war effort, with Bela Lugosi playing a complex character who vacillates between being both hero and villain. The plot is initially unclear, but it builds toward a surprising and compelling ending. The movie offers curious period elements, including a standout performance by Clayton Moore in a romantic role, and may appeal to certain audiences as a historical curiosity.

"On the Run" beautifully captures the spirit of independent cinema with great performances from Michael Imperioli and John Ventimiglia. Set over 24 hours in New York City, the film follows an introspective sales agent and his escaped convict friend as they rediscover themselves through a series of wild events. With its 70s vibe, sensitivity, and humor, the movie is a poignant ode to a fading side of New York and has the potential to become a cult classic.

The reviewer praises the 1972 TV movie "Ghost Story" for its strong writing and acting. They express disappointment with the subsequent TV series, finding it a letdown despite high expectations, but still recommend the original movie highly.

Movie Review: This version of *Picnic* feels slow and lacks the flair of the original film with William Holden. Jay O. Sanders delivers a good performance, especially in scenes with Josh Brolin, but Brolin's portrayal lacks the raw sensuality needed for his character. The casting seems somewhat mismatched, and while Gretchen Moll is lovely, she doesn't fully embody the innocence of her role, and other actors struggle to strike a balance with their characters. The reviewer also questions the relevance of updating the setting to 1966.

Movie Review: The reviewer expresses deep disappointment in *Life Stinks*, describing it as monumentally stupid, boring, and unfunny. Despite being a devoted fan of Mel Brooks, the reviewer felt this film failed to capture Brooks' usual comedic brilliance, comparing it unfavorably to his past works like *Young Frankenstein* and *Spaceballs*. The reviewer even admits to not finishing the movie and advises others to avoid it.

Movie Review: The film effectively captures New York City stereotypes and presents a layered narrative, weaving together different tales to portray the unique lifestyle of Manhattan. It's ideal for viewers who enjoy or can humorously appreciate the essence of New York life.

This is a light-hearted comedy capturing the mischievous nature of childhood, with a focus on lying and dealing with self-created problems. The casting and acting are praised as well as the impressive stunts, making it a fun and entertaining watch.

The reviewer expresses strong discontent with the film, finding it pretentious, shallow, and devoid of any meaningful message. They criticize the idolization of materialistic wealth and the empty, stereotypical characters, and suggest the only redeeming quality was the aerial views of San Francisco. Ultimately, they believe the film was a waste of time and would have preferred anything other than its storyline and characters.
reviews.review2: John Light plays a Stanford drop-out who becomes a successful Dotcom-era entrepreneur, but his rise to the top is threatened by his ambitious partner, Robert Jennings, who once had a relationship with Light’s girlfriend. The story delves into manipulation, debauchery, and the possible downfall of Light's "Digital Dreams" empire, despite efforts by veteran actors like Mia Farrow and Hal Holbrook to add dramatic weight to the film.

reviews.review1: "Kramer vs. Kramer" is a powerful domestic drama about a father, Ted Kramer, who must learn to care for his son after his wife Joanna leaves him, only to face a custody battle when she returns. The film takes a raw look at divorce and family dynamics, with outstanding performances from Dustin Hoffman (Ted) and Meryl Streep (Joanna), both of whom deliver deeply emotional portrayals. With strong writing and direction by Robert Benton, the movie succeeds in transforming a familiar and painful real-life experience into a deeply engaging and thoughtful narrative.

BASEketball is an extremely funny comedy with great acting and a solid plot, though it follows the familiar slackers versus evil rich guy storyline. The reviewer found it hilarious, despite feeling a kid character was unnecessary, though that character contributed to some funny scenes. Overall, it’s a highly enjoyable film worthy of an 8 out of 10.

This John Frankenheimer film has a strong script by Elmore Leonard and stands out as a taut thriller thanks to Frankenheimer's detailed direction. The performances, especially by Robert Trebor and Clarence Williams III, are notable, with Roy Scheider delivering in what could be considered his last good film. The movie effectively blends elements of blackmail, murder, and sleaze, featuring a guilty pleasure mix of drugs, sex, and porno actors in a grimy setting, creating an unforgettable exploitative thriller.

movie_metadata.title: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court
movie_metadata.matched_title: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1989)

reviews.movie: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court
reviews.review1: Movie Review: This film is stylishly directed, beautifully shot, and features excellent performances, particularly by Bing Crosby and Sir Cedric Hardwicke. The musical numbers are delightful, with Crosby in fine voice and Rhonda Fleming showcasing her singing talent. Overall, it's a highly entertaining production with lavish scenes and a universal appeal.

The reviewer found the movie "Cujo" to be somewhat slow in the first half and underwhelming overall. While the acting and technical aspects like photography and editing were fine, the script felt padded and predictable. The titular dog, Cujo, failed to be truly frightening to the reviewer, making the film feel average and something they wouldn't rush to watch again.

Movie Review: The film follows a French Hussar captain during the Napoleonic wars who is captured and sent to a Scottish prisoner of war camp. While there, he navigates romance, friendships, and unexpected family ties. The movie features spirited performances and memorable moments, making it a bit above the typical fare.

Many viewers were disappointed with *Che: Part Two* compared to its predecessor. However, the film accurately portrays the reality of Che's life, where success and ultimate failure are unavoidable contrasts between the two parts. Though the film might feel long and less uplifting, Benicio Del Toro delivers another outstanding performance, and Soderbergh's decision to tell the story as it unfolded in real life is both bold and commendable.

This film is a wild ride full of silly gags, violent slapstick humor, and brilliantly crafted dialogue. Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson return in characters similar to their roles in *Bottom*, delivering the chaotic comedy fans would expect. While it has drawn mistaken comparisons to *Fawlty Towers*, fans of *Bottom* will undoubtedly enjoy it, though it may not appeal to everyone.
reviews.review2: This movie is not sophisticated and embraces a juvenile, idiotic, yet hilarious style. It follows Richie and Eddie running the worst hotel in Britain and getting into chaotic antics with guests, including trying to extract rent from a resident, drinking with power plant workers, and lusting after a famous actress. Fans of Rik Mayall and Ade Edmondson will likely enjoy this irreverent comedy, but it may not appeal to others.

reviews.review1: The reviewer expresses extreme disappointment with the re-make of "Four Brothers." They criticize the movie for its low-quality production values, bad acting, unbelievable settings (like a pine forest in Detroit), and unentertaining plot. The reviewer felt the movie was unworthy of their time and money, preferring the original film over this version.

This review criticizes *Theodore Rex* for being painfully bad and not even entertainingly so, unlike famously awful movies like *Leonard Part 6* and *Battlefield Earth*. The plot is described as nonsensical, with Whoopi Goldberg giving a lackluster performance and the dinosaur character, Theodore Rex, being irritating. Overall, the reviewer found the movie to be an unbearable viewing experience, calling it the worst of Whoopi Goldberg’s career.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: The reviewer, who enjoys watching bad films, claims that *Theodore Rex* is the worst movie they've ever seen. They criticize Whoopi Goldberg’s visible lack of enthusiasm in her performance and the film's poor script and production, asserting that it fails to be even "entertainingly bad."

reviews.review1: This review praises "Never Say Never Again" as a strong entry in the James Bond series, highlighting Sean Connery’s return to the role of Bond and the film's standout villains, including Klaus Maria Brandeau and Barbara Carrera. The reviewer also appreciates the efforts of the film crew, particularly David Dryer’s special effects and Michel Legrand’s music, although they note the score can feel bland in parts. Overall, it's considered a top-tier Bond film and compares favorably to others like "Thunderball" and "Dr. No".

As a retired professional from the medical field, the reviewer appreciates "The Hospital" for its timeless writing and fresh appeal, even decades later. They admire George C. Scott's comedic timing and prefer the film's mental humor over physical comedy. The supporting cast's later success in TV and film is noted, and the reviewer values its suitability as a family film with minimal profanity.

Movie Review: This film delves into the blurred lines between virtual reality and reality, using multiple layers of games within games to challenge the viewer's perception. With nods to Phil K. Dick, Stanley Kubrick, and David Cronenberg’s previous works, it's a mind-bending exploration of identity and existence. The film attempts to deconstruct reality itself, questioning how deeply players, and by extension people, can be immersed in and influenced by virtual and perceived realities.

The review reflects on the director's portrayal of his parents' marital struggles, which are familiar and relatable but ultimately seem dull. The reviewer finds the documentary well-intentioned and the director likable, but criticizes the film for being uninspired, with ordinary filming, music, and story choices. While the subject matter is heartfelt, it fails to engage on a deeper level.

This review is quite critical of the movie's premise, which involves a bullied kid whose soul transfers into a scarecrow after he dies. The reviewer mocks the film’s plot and its campy execution, highlighting the use of cheesy one-liners after the scarecrow kills people, often in absurdly humorous ways. In summary, the review suggests the movie is over-the-top and not enjoyable for the reviewer, labeling it as ridiculous.
reviews.review2: The reviewer finds the movie bizarre but with plenty of humor, stating that it's more fun than scary. They compare it loosely to "Children of the Corn" but prefer "Scarecrow" for its entertainment value.

reviews.review1: This movie features Jay Leno as a Detroit cop and Pat Morita as a Tokyo cop teaming up to retrieve a stolen prototype motor. While the pairing of Leno and Morita creates some amusing and ridiculous moments, the film offers a typical buddy cop dynamic with an entertaining mix of action and humor. Fans of cheesy 80’s films and buddy cop movies might enjoy this light-hearted collaboration.

The reviewer criticizes the film harshly, stating that it lacks imagination, talent, structure, and purpose. They found the excessive profanity, pointless violence, and drawn-out scenes unbearable, calling it a poorly made and disjointed movie about serial killers posing as FBI agents. In comparison, the reviewer believes that even violent films such as "We Were Soldiers" offer redeeming value, which "Surveillance" lacks.

Movie Review: The reviewer expresses deep admiration for *Head*, calling it a unique and unforgettable cult movie with psychedelic visuals and an incredible soundtrack. While polarizing, with some viewers loving it and others disliking it, the reviewer cherishes the film, describing it as a "diamond in the rough" and appreciating its cyclical, introspective nature. They also mention fond memories of watching the Monkees' TV show, linking it to their personal connection with the movie.

Movie Review: This film is Abbott and Costello's only major children's movie, where Costello reads *Jack and the Beanstalk* to a child and then dreams he is Jack in the story. Despite featuring charming singing and whimsical elements, some acting and musical numbers are forgettable. Overall, it's a suitable film for young kids, though parents might want to warn their children not to mimic the behavior of one precocious character.

Cinderella is an enduring Disney classic with a heartfelt story and memorable music that touches upon the timeless longings of the human heart. The film's standout moments include iconic songs like "A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes" and "Bibbidi Bobbidi Boo," even though Cinderella's own character development and motivation leave something to be desired. Despite this, the film features excellent voice performances and a wonderfully subtle villain in Lady Tremaine, making it a comforting and nostalgic watch.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: "Cinderella" is a simple, enchanting Disney classic that brings back the fairy tale genre and played a pivotal role in securing Disney's future. While not one of Disney's most ambitious works, it features charming characters like Cinderella, the Prince, and humorous ones like Jaques, Gus, and the King. Although the movie's soundtrack and visuals may not be its most outstanding aspects, they contribute to the film's enduring appeal, with "Bibiddi Bobiddi Boo" standing out as a memorable song.

reviews.review1: The review discusses Barbet Schroeder’s film *More*, examining its portrayal of youth, drug addiction, and relationships set in a Euro-hippie context. Although the film's performances and screenplay are criticized for lacking depth, Schroeder’s direction, supported by Nestor Almendros’ cinematography and Pink Floyd’s soundtrack, is praised for elevating the film as a thought-provoking, albeit flawed, period piece. Despite its shortcomings, *More* retains value as a visual and atmospheric work reflective of its time.

The reviewer expresses strong dislike for the film "Clerks," criticizing its self-congratulatory tone and what they perceive as unoriginal, uninspired writing. They feel that better, more deserving filmmakers could have benefitted from the resources put into the movie and advocate for more distinctive and visionary work from other filmmakers like John Gulager.

Movie Review: This sequel improves upon its predecessor, 101 Dalmatians, with better filming, more appropriate music, and improved effects. The acting stands out, particularly Glenn Close’s performance, making the film shine. It's a delightful family film with broad appeal, offering fun for both adults and children, and holds potential to become a Disney classic.

Giorgio, Movie Review: This movie is primarily a vehicle for opera legend Luciano Pavarotti, who plays an opera singer grappling with performance anxiety. While the storyline is predictable and not groundbreaking, the real appeal lies in Pavarotti’s charm and the beautiful music featured throughout, including opera arias and popular songs. Though not for everyone, opera and Pavarotti fans will likely enjoy it as a light, fun experience.

Gung Ho is an interesting concept, but the reviewer finds its premise unrealistic. The film centers on an American named Hunt Stevenson (Michael Keaton), who convinces a Japanese auto company to help his struggling town, raising questions about foreign competition and American labor issues. While Keaton gives a credible performance blending comedy and drama, the film ultimately feels lightweight, with a TV movie-like quality and an overly optimistic portrayal of Japanese-American relations.

The review criticizes the movie for being poorly executed despite its star-studded cast. The reviewer feels that Denzel Washington and Clive Owen deliver predictable performances, similar to their previous roles, and expresses disappointment in Jodie Foster’s involvement. The plot is described as clichéd and unconvincing, especially with its unnecessary focus on Holocaust and racism themes. Overall, the reviewer considers the film a waste of time but suggests it might provide some amusement in discussing how bad it is afterward.

Sunny, a cocktail waitress in D.C., accidentally saves an Arab official's life and is thrust into the U.S. government's protocol department. Despite her naïveté and lack of formal skills, she adds charm and comedic value, exposing flaws in the system and learning lessons in honesty. Featuring Goldie Hawn, the film blends humor with political satire, though some might find elements culturally insensitive.

Movie Review: Out To Sea is a light-hearted "golden years" romantic comedy that provides an enjoyable escape from reality. While its budget may not be huge and there are signs of green screen usage, it's still a sweet and fun movie worth watching. Brent Spiner’s performance as the comedic antagonist adds a delightful touch, especially his hilarious take on "Oye Como Va".

Movie Review: The reviewer, a former Marine, reminisces about watching "The D.I." in 1957 and compares it to his own experience in Marine boot camp just a couple of years later. He praises the authenticity of the film, particularly highlighting the tough and harsh nature of drill instructors (D.I.s) whose methods, though perceived as sadistic, were ultimately geared toward keeping soldiers alive in combat. The review underscores the serious training and mentality instilled in Marines, with the primary mission being to kill the enemy.

The reviewer suggests this movie is a lighter, less serious mob drama with Michelle Pfeiffer in the lead role. While they believe Pfeiffer has acted better in other films, they acknowledge her strong performance as a mob wife. The reviewer advises not to take the movie too seriously and mentions Alec Baldwin's solid performance.

Fox's 1940 film "BRIGHAM YOUNG" tells the story of the famous Mormon leader who guided his followers to the Salt Lake Valley after the death of Joseph Smith. The reviewer praises this DVD release for its exceptional extras, including a detailed commentary by James D'Arc, who enriches the viewer's experience by separating historical facts from embellishments. The DVD also includes valuable archival material and newsreel footage, making it a must-have for history and film enthusiasts alike.

The reviewer acknowledges that *Northfork* is a slow-paced film but strongly defends its originality and uniqueness, even comparing it to the work of David Lynch. While some aspects might seem odd and symbolic, the movie’s magical and entrancing atmosphere makes it stand out from typical films. Despite its slow pace, the reviewer found it highly entertaining and gave it an 8/10, praising its creativity and emotional depth.

Movie Review: This review praises "The Cure" for its touching and beautiful story, compelling emotional depth, and great casting, especially highlighting Brad Renfro's performance. The reviewer was initially skeptical about the movie but was drawn in and found the film filled with striking scenes and quotable lines that made them cry. Overall, the reviewer recommends it highly and even purchased a personal copy.

The reviewer disliked "Executive Decision" to begin with, but finds this film even worse in every way. They criticize the acting and unrealistic setting, particularly citing the absurdity of a 747 with only three flight attendants, and numerous plot inconsistencies. The overall sentiment is that the film is so bad it would be preferable to engage in mundane or painful activities instead.

The movie is nostalgic fun for those who watched it as kids, and it holds up well despite its cheesy nature. While it might still be entertaining, newcomers who didn't experience it when they were young might not fully appreciate its charm.

Movie Review: The reviewer is deeply disappointed with *Aeon Flux*, particularly because it diverges from the original series in terms of character motivations, aesthetic, and plot. The complex, morally ambiguous personas of Aeon and Trevor from the show are reduced to simple tropes, and the nuanced setting of a dystopian future is replaced by a generic, utopian visual. Overall, the movie lacks the depth and originality of the series, devolving into a standard good-vs-evil story with little connection to its source material.

The review criticizes "Magnolia" for being a confusing collection of episodes with little coherence and few redeemable characters. While it praises the acting, especially by Tom Cruise and John C. Reilly, it argues that the film's ideas, particularly in its final act, fail to come together meaningfully. Ultimately, the reviewer feels that despite its performative strengths, the film as a whole feels empty and unsatisfying.

*Chop Shop* is a powerful, naturalistic Indie film directed by Ramin Bahrani, centered on a street-smart, 12-year-old boy named Alejandro (Ale) who works at an auto repair shop in Queens' Iron Triangle. Despite the bleak circumstances and harsh environment, the film is a poignant character study about survival, innocence lost, and the enduring bond between Ale and his 16-year-old sister, Isi. Through stark realism, the film avoids glamorized success stories, offering instead a layered narrative that resonates with themes of hardship, hope, and the elusive pursuit of the American Dream.

The reviewer enjoyed the film for being an entertaining escape and praised Sharon Stone's performance as Catherine Trammell, comparing it favorably to her role in the first movie, "Basic Instinct." The reviewer highlights Stone’s captivating presence, sharp one-liners, and the film’s twists, especially the ending. They are excited for the potential of an uncut DVD release.
reviews.review2: The reviewer defends the movie against the negative reviews and praises it for its plot, which they found solid and without major flaws. They note that it follows a similar pattern to the first film, Basic Instinct, but with a clearer plot. The performances, especially Sharon Stone’s, are highlighted, and the reviewer advises viewers to watch it themselves rather than rely on critical opinions.

reviews.review1: Movie Review: This review praises *One Crazy Summer* as a perfect example of a great American teen comedy, highlighting its blend of slapstick, surreal, and dry humor. The reviewer particularly appreciates the performances of Bobcat Goldthwait and John Cusack and emphasizes that while the movie is immature and screwball, it is also hilariously entertaining.

The review criticizes the film's heavy reliance on horror clichés, from predictable plot points such as a van breaking down to a sole female survivor, making the movie feel uninspired and overly familiar. While the cinematography and music are improvements over the director's previous work, *Darkhunters*, the film ultimately misses the mark of being clever or different, and the director’s commentary only emphasizes the lack of self-awareness and arrogance within the production. Ultimately, the film feels like a forgettable entry in the bad horror movie canon.

Movie Review: This documentary follows filmmaker Doug Block as he continues filming about his parents even after his mother's death and uncovers surprising truths along the way. The film skillfully weaves the story of his mother’s vibrant life while reflecting on familial relationships, aging, and personal revelations without venturing into melodrama. It's an intimate, emotionally resonant examination of Block's family, urging viewers to reevaluate their own perceptions of their parents' lives.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: This documentary delivers an emotional and thoughtful experience, presenting a deeply personal and honest narrative. It carefully balances between personal truth and potential exploitation, and successfully tells the story of a couple’s personal struggles in a way that feels informative rather than pessimistic. The movie prompts deep reflection and offers a fresh perspective on marriage and relationships.

reviews.review1: Movie Review: The reviewer criticizes Michael Moore's film "Roger & Me" as propaganda veiled as humor, expressing disdain for its messages and style. They suggest Moore uses shallow tactics to attract viewers and accuse him of fueling hatred and isolationism. Despite acknowledging some self-deprecation in Moore's approach, the reviewer ultimately finds the filmmaker's characterization of Roger Smith hypocritical.

Movie Review: The film is episodic and a bit repetitive, with flashbacks that don't advance a central story but provide insights into the characters. While Noel Coward's acting is criticized as wooden and lacking emotion, David Lean’s technical expertise and visual storytelling elevate the film. It's an interesting debut for Lean, showcasing his editing skills, though it’s more of a propaganda piece than a deep or penetrating narrative.

The review highlights that "Who's That Girl?" is not a deep film but is highly entertaining. It is described as a campy and joyful movie with plenty of humor and few dull moments. The reviewer fondly recalls the performances of the cast, including Griffin Dunne and Bibi Besch, making the overall experience a delightful one.

movie_metadata.title: Lady and the Tramp II: Scamp's Adventure
movie_metadata.matched_title: Lady and the Tramp II: Scamp's Adventure (2001)

reviews.movie: Lady and the Tramp II: Scamp's Adventure
reviews.review1: This is an entertaining Disney sequel that pleasantly diverges from traditional repetition seen in follow-up films. The story focuses on Scamp, the son of Tramp, as he ventures into unknown surroundings, learns important life lessons and overcomes challenges on his journey to self-discovery. The voice acting by well-known actors like Scott Wolf, Alyssa Milano, and Mickey Rooney is superb, making it a well-made family movie.

The reviewer clearly disliked the movie, finding it neither funny nor entertaining and comparing it to torture. Although they didn't enjoy the film, they were captivated by actress Rhona Mitra, which may inspire them to watch her other works.

The reviewer compares 'No Reservations' unfavorably to its original, 'Mostly Martha'. While Catherine Zeta Jones is talented, the movie failed to deliver the strong emotional and sensory experience of its predecessor. The food and characters in 'No Reservations' lacked passion and depth, leaving the reviewer disappointed by the overall execution.

Movie Review: The reviewer criticizes Jerry Bruckheimer productions for being shallow and often wasting potential, noting that they typically do well at the box office but fail to impress critics. They find *Crimson Tide* slightly better than other Bruckheimer films but still unconvincing, especially due to an unrealistic storyline about nuclear warfare post-Cold War. While acknowledging competent direction and performances, the reviewer claims the film would have had more impact during the height of Cold War tensions.

This movie overlooks the true story of Phoolan Devi, as director Shekhar Kapoor created the film without ever meeting her. Despite the opportunity to shed light on the struggles of low-caste women in Indian society, the film reduces Phoolan Devi's character to a revenge-driven stereotype, appealing more to western audiences than accurately portraying her life.

Johnnie To's ELECTION is an exciting and well-made film about an Asian godfather's scheming and the violent struggles within a mobster society. The film is stylishly scored, with interesting performances and a bitter, impactful ending. While violent, it is less so by modern standards and presents morally ambiguous characters, much like Coppola's works.

Movie Review: The reviewer criticizes this 1986 movie, calling it a boring and predictable soap opera. Despite stars like Mary Tyler Moore, Ted Danson, and Christine Lahti, the plot revolves around an affair and a subsequent death but feels stale and unoriginal. The reviewer was disappointed, stating that even the actors' talents couldn't save the movie, labeling it a forgettable experience with little replay value.

The film, originally written 40 years ago, feels dated and superficial in its 2003 adaptation. While the message of the film comes through, it is presented in a clichéd manner, with some characters, especially Salman Khan's, feeling unrealistic. Amitabh Bachchan delivers a strong performance, especially in his final speech, while supporting actors like Hema Malini and Divya Dutta are also noteworthy.

Movie Review: The film adaptation of Tom Wolfe's satirical novel falters due to problematic miscasting, including Tom Hanks and Melanie Griffith, who fail to capture the essence of their characters. While Brian De Palma delivers a visually polished product, his direction lacks the depth and nuance needed to make the film compelling, leaving the satire ineffective and devoid of emotional impact.

Movie Review: A dull made-for-TV movie that premiered on TBS, where Antonio and Janine chase a killer computer virus with little excitement. The movie is notable for debuting the same weekend as the real-life 'Melissa' virus.

The reviewer finds the movie to be among the worst they have seen. They believe it doesn't improve over what they perceive as a lackluster predecessor and feels the plot goes nowhere quickly, rating it poorly.

Movie Review: This is an unusual fantasy film that features some terrifying moments, despite its PG-13 rating. It's well-directed by Bernard Rose with a beautiful musical score, though Charlotte Burke's weak performance as the lead detracts from its greatness. Overall, the movie boasts strong performances from the rest of the cast, particularly Elliott Spiers and Glenne Headley, and remains a sleeper hit worth revisiting.

Movie Review: While the 3-D animation was the highlight of the film, other aspects such as the plot and character development were weak. The characters lacked depth, and the filmmakers seemed to rely too heavily on the visual spectacle. The appearance of Buzz Aldrin at the end undermined the story by pointing out its implausibility, further diminishing the overall experience.

Movie Review: This movie, based on a true story, showcases how love can prevail even during times of war and tragedy. The breathtaking scenery of Cephalonia, Greece, and the stellar performances of Nicolas Cage and Penélope Cruz bring the story to life. Their portrayal of a Mediterranean couple growing closer during war leaves a deep emotional impact.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: The reviewer enjoyed the movie, especially the developing relationship between Pelagia and Captain Corelli. They were emotionally invested in the characters and appreciated the happy ending, recommending it as a good movie for a relaxing evening.

reviews.review1: Movie Review: The reviewer, an Orthodox woman, expresses strong disapproval of the film "Kadosh," stating it misrepresents the Orthodox Chasidic community and is filled with inaccuracies, particularly regarding religious practices. She criticizes the portrayal of Orthodox life as oppressive, especially toward women, and feels that the film pushes a negative and unrealistic narrative. Despite acknowledging the love story's charm, she finds it lacking credibility and feels the film overall is more of a poorly executed critique of Orthodox Judaism.

The review praises *West Point* as a highly enjoyable film about honor and friendship, with William Haines showcasing his acting talents in both comedic and serious scenes. Although it may not match the quality of his earlier work due to the lack of a co-star like Lon Chaney, it still stands as an effective tribute to the Army. Joan Crawford is highlighted for her supporting role and early stardom, with noted quality production supported by the War Department and enhanced by restoration and a new score.

Niagara, Movie Review: A beautiful and heartbreaking film where Robin Tunney delivers a sincere and convincing portrayal of a young woman dealing with Tourette's syndrome. Her performance is compelling and has left a lasting impression on the reviewer.

Movie Review: The reviewer found the movie to be loud, with poor audio clarity and bad accents, especially from Richard Masur. They criticize the miscasting, strange makeup, and unnecessary scenes, particularly mentioning Kristofferson’s unlikeable character and Walken’s untimely death. Overall, they found no redeeming qualities in the film and were glad it negatively impacted the director’s career and United Artists.

Movie Review: This film follows Joe, a foul-mouthed, conservative working-class man who befriends a wealthier opposite, Bill Compton, after Compton’s daughter overdoses. The two men later search for Melissa, Compton’s daughter, leading to a violent and chaotic ending that echoes themes found in *Taxi Driver*. Though it touches on anti-violence and anti-racist messages, the film falls short as Joe ultimately becomes a participant in the very things he despises, leaving the film's final message ambiguous.

Movie Review: This review highlights that *Seven Pounds* is a somber, emotionally charged movie centered around a main character struggling with guilt over a significant moral failing. The story is gradually revealed, which keeps the viewer engaged, and the performances, particularly by Will Smith, are noted as solid. While the film is thought-provoking, it leaves the viewer a bit sad in the end, making it more suited for those who enjoy reflective drama rather than action-packed entertainment.

Movie Review: The reviewer appreciates the historical time setting and effort but finds the film's visual quality too blurry and out of focus, causing discomfort. They believe the style might have been intentional but too harsh on the eyes, contrasting it with "Band of Brothers," which effectively used graininess without sacrificing visual clarity. Lastly, they emphasize that movies should balance CGI with real sets and locations for a better viewing experience.

Movie Review: The film follows two teenagers from the north-east of England as they try to raise money for season tickets to their favorite football team, but the tone turns increasingly grim over time. Despite being marketed as a comedy, it is filled with depressing stereotypes and unlikable characters, making it more bleak than humorous. Although the lead actors give good performances, their miscast accents and the film's clichéd portrayal of Tyneside leave the reviewer disappointed, especially when compared to other more uplifting films like *Billy Elliot* or the director's previous work, *Little Voice* .

The reviewer felt disappointed by "To Die For", which lacked both humor and sexiness despite initial expectations. While praising the performances of the actors, especially Thomas Arklie, the reviewer found the characters uninteresting and the script lacking. The ending was described as sappy, and the reviewer recommends "Parting Glances" as a better alternative for those seeking a film about gay relationships and AIDS.
reviews.review2: The reviewer initially expected a cheesy vampire film but was pleasantly surprised. They found it to be a good mix of romance and horror, with stylish set-pieces and unexpected gore. Though a bit corny at times, it satisfies vampire enthusiasts and comes highly recommended.

reviews.review1: Movie Review: This is another typical Steven Seagal movie, where he plays a professional thief who is double-crossed and seeks revenge after escaping prison. Although it's slightly better than some of Seagal's other films like "Submerged" and features a Las Vegas location, it suffers from overused action scenes, predictable plot, and frequent use of stunt doubles. The movie lacks realism, and many familiar actors seem to be going through the motions. Seagal’s formula has grown stale and repetitive.

This review is highly negative, criticizing the movie for its ending and lack of a sequel. The reviewer finds the film poorly done, rushed, and suggestive of exploitation for profit. They compare it unfavorably to another film, "Outbreak," and advise others to avoid it due to its weak characters, poor acting, and hype.

Movie Review: The review describes "Paranoid Park" as an overly artsy and ultimately meaningless film that focuses too much on superficial elements, such as excessive scenes of teenagers in their underwear or engaging in intimate moments. While praised for its cinematography and soundtrack, the reviewer finds the film to be boring, uninteresting, and lacking the substance found in better coming-of-age films like "Thirteen" and "Elephant." The review ends with a hope that the director, Gus Van Sant, will return to form with his next project, "Milk."

Movie Review: This film features a polished performance by Melvyn Douglas as a detective torn between love and duty, with Joan Blondell offering a delightful portrayal as his enduring sweetheart. While it doesn’t quite achieve classic status, it presents a light, fast-paced adventure resembling screwball comedies or Thin Man-type films, making it an enjoyable 85-minute ride. Though it may not have spawned a series, it leaves viewers wishing for more films like it.

This film, directed by Wayne Wang, brilliantly showcases the chemistry between Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman, delving into the complexities of their dysfunctional relationship. Sarandon's believable portrayal of a narcissistic parent and Portman's resilient and dignified adolescent character drive the narrative, which balances emotional depth without sinking into melodrama. The film offers a satisfying and thoughtful conclusion, making it a rewarding watch for those seeking both challenge and entertainment.

The review criticizes the film for its disjointed portrayal of the main character at different ages, with neither the actors nor their experiences aligning well. Aside from the unique narrative technique where each version of Wirey narrates his part, the reviewer finds little redeeming quality and advises avoiding the film.

Movie Review: This is a delightful musical featuring Frank Sinatra, Gene Kelly, and Kathryn Grayson that earned multiple Oscar nominations, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Kelly. The story revolves around Kelly helping Sinatra find love, but ultimately falling for the same woman. The film is filled with memorable musical performances, with dazzling singing by Grayson and impressive dance routines by Kelly and Sinatra.

The review praises the Australian horror movie *Black Water* for its suspenseful plot, believable characters, and effective shock moments. While the reviewer notes the film's simple, compact story and limited setting, they commend the filmmakers for maximizing tension without leading to tedium. Overall, they regard *Black Water* as a refreshing entry in the horror genre, particularly for its memorable crocodile antagonist and atmospheric score.

The reviewer reminisces about seeing *Grey Gardens* on British television in the 1980s and describes it as one of the most extraordinary films they’ve ever seen, particularly impressed by the strong bond between mother and daughter despite their difficult circumstances. Rather than finding the film sad or exploitative, the reviewer highlights the resilience, poise, and humor of its central characters, expressing bittersweet sentiments about its status as a 'cult' classic and its transition into an off-Broadway musical.

Fast Women, The reviewer strongly advises against watching the film, criticizing its episodic and predictable script, poor acting, and even the music. The reviewer is particularly disturbed by the appearance of the main character and finds little entertainment value in the film, suggesting even mundane activities would be a better use of time. The only positive note is Louise Lasser's performance, although it's mentioned she deserves a much better movie.

The reviewer finds the film to be a hilarious and well-acted movie involving an unlikely duo of Scarlett Johansson and Woody Allen, who pursue a lead from a ghost about a murderer. The review praises Woody Allen's performance and suggests he is capable of making a strong comeback in his career. Overall, the movie is considered entertaining and worth watching.
reviews.review2: Movie Review: The reviewer, a long-time fan of Woody Allen's works, expresses major disappointment with the movie "Scoop." They criticize the lazy plot, uninspired performances from Scarlett Johansson and Hugh Jackman, and Woody Allen’s own unconvincing acting. The review laments Allen's seemingly declining creativity and suggests he should step away from acting before his legacy is further tarnished.

reviews.review1: This is a touching movie about a mother's unconditional love and the challenges she faces raising her daughter on her own. The reviewer praises the performances of the entire cast, especially Bette Midler and Trini Alvarado. They highly recommend the film and feel it deserves a perfect rating, going even beyond Roger Ebert’s praise.

Movie Review: The film "Caravaggio" is visually stunning, with impressive cinematography that effectively recreates the painter's works. However, the movie falls short with its caricatured approach, lacking depth beyond 80s stereotypes, and failing to capture the complexity of the artist's violent and dangerous life. While it satirizes the London art scene, it ultimately feels shallow, despite its aesthetic beauty.

I took a group of young people who were the same age as the protagonists and it appealed to us all. The supporting characters, particularly the one portrayed by Wilson, were well-acted, and the movie caters to an audience transitioning between childhood and adolescence. With reasonable depictions of youthful rebellion, a compelling school setting, and great music, the film is enjoyable for both teens and adults alike. Fans of Holes will find similarities in tone and style.

Movie Review: Giorgino is a rare romantic adventure film that may feel long to some viewers but is still highly recommended. It draws comparisons to "Doctor Zhivago" with some elements reminiscent of "Sleepy Hollow," making it a must-see.

Movie Review: The reviewer expresses surprise and appreciation for *The Wind*, a lesser-known film that strayed from the marketing's misleading horror-based description, instead offering a dark drama about four friends whose bad choices spiral out of control. They praise the film's use of unknown actors, natural dialogue, and lack of traditional Hollywood effects like excessive violence and nudity, which allow the story's metaphor of society and self-preservation to shine. The reviewer highly recommends the film to those who enjoy unique, thought-provoking movies, despite its under-the-radar release.

The last (I believe) of the movies The Boys made with Hal Roach>

Movie Review: This film marks the end of The Boys' collaborations with Hal Roach, with some of their last truly funny performances before moving on to less successful projects. Though there are weak moments like those involving the "lung tester," the movie still highlights the charm and comic genius of the duo. Richard Cramer's appearance as Nick Granger adds some delightful menace, and standout scenes such as the duo eating their synthetic meal solidify it as a memorable entry in the Laurel & Hardy canon for their fans.

Randolph Scott plays a hot-headed hero who confronts a corrupt uncle involved in a robbery. After forming a partnership with a businesswoman and her brother, Scott faces repeated schemes to destroy their opposition, including the arrival of a femme fatale. While the plot is typical for the genre, with Scott overcoming the antagonist and getting the girl, it's well-executed and entertaining, making it worth watching.

Despite some minor flaws and contrived plot points, the film delivers a positive portrayal of two characters who help each other through life's struggles. While the script could have been refined, the performances by De Niro and Fonda, and the way the characters complement each other, make it a good watch. The magic of the film shines in scenes like the one in the library, highlighting the theme of mutual support.

Movie Review: The reviewer praises Meryl Streep's performance, noting her ability to bring depth, intelligence, and empathy to her character, Kate, in *One True Thing*. While the film's script and William Hurt's performance are described as less impressive or somewhat standard, Streep elevates the film with her complex portrayal. Her ability to create subtle yet powerful moments makes the film notable despite its overall mediocrity.

Despite some underdeveloped aspects, the movie is an emotionally moving drama with strong performances by Richard Gere and Diane Lane. The film focuses on two people recovering from broken marriages who find healing in each other. While certain themes could have been explored further, particularly regarding the emotional development of the characters, it's a touching movie that left a lasting impression and is worth viewing.

This movie is extremely funny and enjoyable, with a cast that blends humor and experience well. Kevin Kline and Tom Selleck perform excellently, with humor that is often goofy and exaggerated, especially in the beginning. Joan Cusack also stands out with her comedic timing, making the film an enjoyable watch if you want light-hearted entertainment.

This review praises *Paris Is Burning* as a groundbreaking and essential film in the portrayal of black and Latin gay culture, emphasizing its authenticity and impact. The reviewer highlights its unique blend of humor, social critique, and enduring relevance 15 years after its release. They also commend the director for effectively capturing the subject matter, even though she wasn’t part of the community.

Truly amazing film with a prophetic vision of a dystopian future where the Earth is overpopulated, resources are exhausted, and the environment is severely damaged. Charlton Heston shines as a detective investigating a murder, alongside a memorable last performance by Edward G. Robinson. The film’s visuals and atmospheric use of classical music, particularly Beethoven, add intensity to its disturbing but gripping narrative.

The film has a poor overall execution with a nonsensical plot despite featuring decent talents like Dennis Hopper and Stuart Gordon. While the reviewer appreciated minor moments such as the "square pigs" and a unique cyborg love scene, they found the film overwhelmingly bad and advice against watching it.

The reviewer advises not to read anything about "Cypher" to avoid spoilers, and states the movie offers a great experience with its intelligent and twisted story. The film is described as more of a psychological thriller set in the world of corporate espionage rather than traditional sci-fi. Its actors deliver strong performances, and the film’s complex plot and satisfying ending surpass the director's other works.

A great performance by Emily Grace! The story keeps the viewer guessing with some unpredictable twists, and Emily Grace shines in her portrayal of "Alice." The plot is refreshing, with intriguing supporting characters and a satisfying ending. The reviewer is now a fan of Emily Grace and looks forward to seeing more of her work.

A monotonous film about a drunk, unemployable loser named Henry Chinaski, played by Matt Dillon, who drifts through life without accomplishing much. While Dillon's performance as the alter ego of Charles Bukowski is decent, the movie itself feels uneventful and tiresome, focusing largely on Chinaski's alcohol-fueled, futile existence. It lacks a compelling narrative or engaging characters, making for an unnecessarily long and dull experience.

Movie Review: This Ealing comedy is regarded as one of the best, centered around a portion of Pimlico, London, which is discovered to be part of Burgundy and therefore exempt from UK law. The film follows the residents' humorous and determined battle to keep their newfound status while rationing food and water, leading to a touching climax where their neighbors come to their aid. With stellar performances and a balanced moral, this film is praised for its superb acting and perfect comedic tone.

I love a good Western movie, but this was more like watching a play on stage or an act at the local street carnival show. I could only stand 38 minutes of it in hopes that it would improve, but it only got worse and I had to end it. Each actor(s) stated the lines as if reading directly from the script or cue cards. There was too much predictability to the lines and actions not as if a natural occurrence or conversation. The wig on Rachel Kimsey was obvious. The actresses playing Native American sisters, could have played non-native parts and should have. Wardrobe for the Native Americans could have been better and a little more authentic looking. If I decide to watch it with any friends in the future, I will do so, not with the expectations of watching a good Western, but with the expectations of watching an amateur comedy film production.>

Review Summary: The reviewer found the movie disappointing, criticizing the acting, dialogue, and predictable plot. They felt it lacked authenticity in its portrayal of Native American characters and had issues with costuming. They felt it was more akin to a poorly produced comedy than a good Western.

Movie Review: This film is highly gripping and deeply emotional, providing powerful insight into the struggles and lives of people in South Africa. The acting and script are exceptional, keeping the viewer captivated despite the horrific and heart-wrenching events. A must-watch that leaves a palpable impact.

Movie Review: Eaten Alive is a disappointing cannibal movie that pales in comparison to similar films like Cannibal Ferox. The film lacks tension, suspense, and effective practical effects, while also underusing its locations and characters. Despite its outrageous scenes, the movie ultimately fails to evoke shock or stay true to its genre's tradition.

This is a fun and exaggerated comedy that offers an enjoyable portrayal of the soap opera world with its implausible and over-the-top storylines. Kevin Kline and Sally Field shine in their roles with memorable performances, alongside a strong supporting cast that includes Whoopi Goldberg and Robert Downey Jr. The film is perfect for anyone who wants a good laugh and is willing to go with the absurdity of the plot.

This review praises the film's impressive cinematography, with beautifully crafted visuals and excellent use of color. The reviewer admired Park Chan Wook's direction for creating a dark and convincing universe and appreciated the touches of dark humor. However, they found the story sometimes lacking in coherence and felt it dragged at times, though they still recommend the film for its vision and uniqueness.

Certain elements of this film feel dated, such as an all-white male crew, and it suffers from some slow self-admiration typical of pre-Star Wars Science Fiction. However, it perfectly captures the essence of Golden Age Science Fiction, including the use of "electronic tonalities" for its musical score. The plot, based on Shakespeare's "The Tempest," brings a maturity to the genre, with Robbie the Robot inspiring future sci-fi creations.

Speed Racer is a nostalgic classic that can be enjoyed by viewers of all ages. The reviewer fondly remembers the catchy opening, unique car designs like the Mach 5, and the intriguing mystery of Racer-X. While some tweaks were made from the manga, the overall execution of the show left a positive impression, making it timeless and enjoyable even years after initially watching it.

"Magic" isn't too strong a word for the spell this film weaves. You find yourself relaxing, and seeing others in a more benevolent light... Any movie that has that civilizing an effect on viewers deserves serious attention. Seldom are we soaked in beauty like this. As if that weren't enough, it's funny. Performances are, without exception, extraordinary, but special mention must be made of the miraculous Miranda Richardson, and the superb Josie Walker - both open like roses. Why ISN'T this film on DVD? It deserves to live forever.

Movie Review: Sam Elliott plays a trustworthy but flawed cop, Falon, whose loyalty and thirst for revenge after his partner’s murder drive much of the plot. While wrestling with alcoholism, Falon partners with a rookie (Esai Morales) to uncover the real culprit, leading to an intense investigation laden with layers of distrust. With strong acting, a dramatic conclusion, and moments of humor, the movie leaves a lasting impression and is worth watching multiple times.

Movie Review: The movie, based on Frank Frazetta's art, successfully captures the feel of his fantasy illustrations with its unique animation style employing rotoscope. The plot includes captivating characters, exciting action sequences, a menacing villain, and a compelling story, reminiscent of the best Conan comics. Overall, it offers a much more satisfying experience compared to other live-action adaptations of the genre.

One of the most unheralded great works of animation, “Twice Upon a Time” excels in its sophisticated use of the "cut-out" animation method. The vocal performances, particularly Lorenzo Music as Ralph, are a standout, and the "accidental nightmare" sequence is highly praised as one of the finest moments in animation.

Movie Review: This film adapts Shakespeare's classic themes of cross-dressing and comedic mischief to a modern setting, using his timeless plot devices to great effect. The young, attractive cast delivers strong performances, with the climax centering around a soccer game reminiscent of Bend It Like Beckham. It’s a lighthearted and charming take on Shakespeare’s works, particularly comedies like Twelfth Night.

Movie Review: The reviewer fondly recalls "April Love" as one of their favorite childhood movies, praising it as a timeless, family-friendly classic, especially for its clean romance, compelling story, and great songs. They highlight the strong performances by Pat Boone and Shirley Jones, and express regret that movies like this are no longer made.

The reviewer expresses disappointment that the film focuses too much on the bigotry and violence surrounding LGBTQ individuals in rural areas rather than celebrating the lives of the small-town gay community. They were hoping for more representation of the gay individuals who frequent the bar rather than those who oppose it. The film feels more like a warning than a meaningful exploration of rural gay life.

The review praises Will Smith's performance in the romantic comedy *Hitch*, where he plays a date doctor who helps men improve their romantic lives. The reviewer particularly highlights Will Smith's charm and Kevin James' comedic role, referencing his funny dance moves. There's also mention of a humorous scene involving an allergic reaction on Hitch's face. The review briefly diverts into personal anecdotes and references, making the core points of the movie mixed with sentimental musings.

Walking With Dinosaurs is a highly praised documentary that is both educational and captivating for dinosaur enthusiasts and newcomers alike. The reviewer fondly recalls watching it and being immediately engrossed by its detailed depiction of different dinosaurs across various periods. The documentary offers an immersive experience and successfully transports viewers back in time, with its memorable portrayal of species such as Diplodocus and a caring mother T-Rex.

Victor Nunez delivers an unsentimental and poetic portrayal of a young woman's emotional journey, with an almost literary quality to the storytelling. While the film explores deep themes, it can be slow at times, which detracts from its overall impact. Ashley Judd shines in her debut role as Ruby, providing an effortless and captivating performance that she has yet to surpass in her later work.

The film falls short due to its simplistic plot, poor direction, and subpar acting, with the exception of standout performances by Kathleen Turner and Antony Perkins. Turner is compelling as her dual character and Perkins excels as a perverted reverend, but their efforts cannot salvage the movie. Overall, it's a weak film that only die-hard fans of either actor may want to watch.

Uninspired direction and a clichéd plot about an adulterous couple don’t create much emotional impact, despite fine performances from Harrison Ford and Kristen Scott-Thomas. The film’s slow-moving narrative lacks momentum, leaving the climax feeling underwhelming.

The movie is a farce with atrocious acting, particularly from Bill Pullman. The script gives the characters no opportunity for believable interaction, and while it tries to shock the viewer, the attempts feel forced. The only redeeming aspect is the quiet, intense performance from the little girl, Stephanie, but overall, the film is violent without purpose, filled with bad acting, and ultimately not recommended.

This film, directed by Harry Beaumont, features a slow-moving plot with only a few humorous moments and fuzzy visuals. Despite an interesting cast that includes Ann Harding, Frank Morgan, and Jessie Ralph, the pacing and backdrop detract from the experience. The only redeeming qualities are Ralph's overbearing character and the mercifully short runtime, although the 1992 British remake by the BBC seems to have left a better impression.

Mystery Men is a fun and witty movie with a superb cast that delivers memorable performances, particularly Greg Kinnear, Geoffrey Rush, and Tom Waits. While the pacing may be off at times and the flashy visuals can overshadow character development, the film offers numerous great moments that make it worth watching multiple times. Overall, it stands out as a more clever and enjoyable film than typical comedies.
reviews.review2: This movie is a fun and quirky take on the superhero genre, featuring a group of misunderstood misfits trying to save the city with determination despite their limitations. It may not be a polished film, but the jokes operate on different levels, and the cast fits their roles perfectly. While it’s not for everyone, it offers more depth than it's given credit for and shouldn’t be compared unfavorably to more mainstream comedies.

reviews.review1: The review praises "Beat Street" for its break-dancing scenes and compares it favorably to "Flashdance" and "Footloose" in terms of dance representation. The reviewer highlights the authentic portrayal of hip-hop culture, including elements like gang life, graffiti, and rap music as key aspects of the film. It also mentions a tragic yet impactful fight scene involving the character Ramon, and speculates on a cameo appearance by Sheila E. during a dance scene.

Movie Review: The movie starts out with some promise, but quickly loses its appeal when it reveals that the story is a movie within a movie. Some of the characters, particularly a girl in the theater, are irritating, and overall, the film is strange but ultimately not enjoyable.

Movie Review: The reviewer had a surprisingly positive experience with *Hunter Prey*, praising its ability to engross them despite having a low budget and limited props. They appreciated the mystery of the plot, the restraint in the use of CGI, and the emphasis on acting rather than special effects. Some minor criticisms were directed towards confusing character behavior and overly mysterious moments, but overall, they felt the movie was engaging and offered better storytelling than certain well-known franchises.

The review praises the 2009 film "Earth" for its breathtaking footage and majestic depiction of nature, showcasing both the beauty and cruelty of life in the wild. The narration by James Earl Jones adds gravity to the experience, though the reviewer wishes the film had been released in IMAX and been longer. Overall, it's a visually stunning documentary that leaves the door open for more similar productions.

Movie Review: This film features Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy, a popular comedy duo, in a story where Ollie's need for peace clashes with comedic chaos. The duo ends up adrift at sea with an escaped convict after a series of mishaps involving a trumpet, a goat, and mistaken identities. While there are moments of classic comedy, the reviewer feels it ultimately falls short, despite its nostalgic value.

This review critiques certain casting choices, especially Bacall's misfit as an upper-class Englishwoman, while praising performances by Boyer, Lorre, and Paxinou. The dialogue is seen as somewhat unrealistic but serves Graham Greene's purpose of conveying a political message about England during wartime. The review also appreciates Greene's preservation of diverse characters.

This movie suffers from poor dialogue, lack of character development, weak tension, and an unengaging story. The action scenes feel cheap and thrown together, with little thought behind them. While Daan Schuurmans puts in effort, it ultimately cannot save what is otherwise a disappointing film.

It resembles Quentin Tarantino's films like PULP FICTION or RESERVOIR DOGS and seems inspired by that style. Despite being a low-budget B-movie, it offers a captivating gangster plot with humor, good performances, and an enjoyable soundtrack. Overall, it's well-produced and entertaining, worth a score of 7/10.

Movie Review: The plot may not be elaborate, but the strong performances by actors like Christopher Meloni and Janel Moloney make this movie a worthwhile watch. With solid character portrayals and intriguing cameos, it's an enjoyable sleeper film.

The review describes Dario Argento's *Opera* as a Giallo-style film, but it diverges by focusing more on tension and grisly death scenes rather than traditional mystery elements. The review praises the compelling visual horror, particularly eye-focused trauma, and inventive death sequences, although it criticizes the unrealistic air duct plot device and the film's disappointing finale. Overall, *Opera* is recognized for its artistic yet brutal death scenes, with particular emphasis on the killer’s tormenting of the protagonist, Betty.

The review highlights the movie's exploration of human relationships, blending charm, humor, and insightful writing. Morgan Freeman and Paz Vega's performances are praised, with the film taking viewers on an intimate journey of self-discovery. Overall, the movie is recommended for those who enjoy thoughtful narratives about human connections, with a bonus suggestion to watch *The Pursuit of Happiness*.

movie_metadata.title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus
movie_metadata.matched_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

reviews.movie: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus
reviews.review1: This movie is a fictionalized and bizarre take on the life of famous photographer Diane Arbus. While it seemingly tries to explain her fascination with oddities, the storyline involving a wolfman who moves in above her and with whom she becomes obsessed feels strange and fantastical. The movie fails to leave a lasting impression, and its odd elements make it hard to recommend.

This is an intricate, slow-unfolding film that features stunning ensemble performances, especially by lead actress Summer Phoenix. While the narrator may feel out of place, the movie's beauty lies in its unpredictable and concise storytelling. With a running time of 163 minutes, it presents rich, breathtaking moments and leaves a lasting impression as a thought-provoking cinematic experience.

This reviewer was deeply impacted by the movie, admiring its raw and realistic portrayal of violence and life’s consequences. They contrasted it with Crash, praising Grand Canyon for its truthful approach to difficult issues like racism and the human condition, and appreciated its subtle and unresolved conclusion.

This review criticizes the film for its inauthentic portrayal of Japanese culture, particularly the representation of Geishas, and highlights numerous inaccuracies in the depiction of Japanese traditions such as dances, music, and other cultural elements. While the reviewer acknowledges that some Chinese actors effectively portrayed Japanese characters, they feel the film ultimately missed an opportunity to bring a meaningful understanding of Japan to a Western audience.

movie_metadata.title: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me
movie_metadata.matched_title: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me (1992)

reviews.movie: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me
reviews.review1: The reviewer harshly criticizes the movie, labeling it as overly disturbing and psychologically unsettling. They argue that David Lynch's storytelling, both in the movie and the related TV series, lacks originality and is more a grotesque portrayal of misery and immorality than an artistic statement. The reviewer strongly advises against watching it, calling it a waste of time and full of unpleasant themes.

Movie Review: The reviewer finds some redeeming qualities in the film, such as its ability to capture the Australian heat and the charming animation sequences. However, they feel the characters' inner conflicts are overemphasized, leading to a TV-like experience rather than a cinematic one. The performances are inconsistent, and heavy-handed use of pop music detracts from the film, ultimately making it an unsatisfying viewing experience.

The reviewer was disappointed with Naqoyqatsi, the third part of the Qatsi trilogy, finding it chaotic and lacking the thematic depth and global scope of its predecessors. The themes of civilized warfare and globalization were poorly developed, with too much focus on the USA. Although the Philip Glass score was described as "inoffensive," it ultimately did little to improve the film's disjointed presentation.

This review provides an in-depth reflection on the cultural and historical significance of *The Lone Ranger*. It traces its origins from a local radio play in Detroit, created by George W. Trendle and Fran Striker, to its rise as a beloved television series. With actors like Clayton Moore and Jay Silverheels, the show captured a part of American folklore during pivotal moments in history, and its themes of justice and fairness had a lasting impact on American audiences.

The review critiques Uwe Boll's "Seed" for being a misguided attempt at creating social commentary and establishing a slasher icon. The film's antagonist, Maxwell Seed, is described as an uninspired villain, lacking the iconic presence of horror figures like Michael Myers or Jason Voorhees. The review highlights poor filmmaking techniques, a tedious narrative, and ineffective characters, ultimately calling it a bloated, unexciting movie experience.

The reviewer praises the "Tarzan and His Mate" for its well-written script, exciting action sequences, and seamless blending of studio and location shots. They also discuss in detail the controversial scenes involving nudity, defending their perception of authenticity. The reviewer notes that the movie reflects the racial attitudes of its time and advises modern viewers to understand it in that historical context.

This review praises the movie for blending familiar elements like vampires, martial arts, and special effects into something refreshingly new. Wesley Snipes is lauded for his strong performance as the titular character, while Steven Dorff delivers a compelling villain. The choreography, acting, and overall production quality are highlighted, leaving the reviewer hopeful for a similarly good sequel.

This movie clearly has an agenda, promoting xenophobic elements and portraying characters in overly simplistic and often offensive stereotypes. The reviewer criticizes the film's narrative as divisive, with a focus on vilifying "gringos" and suggesting danger or malevolence outside one's home country, particularly targeting Mexico. The review expresses frustration with the so-called "true story" tag as a manipulative tool to push an extreme ideological stance.

The movie 'Homicide' starts with the tone of a standard crime drama but gradually shifts to focus on the Jewish identity of one of the detectives investigating the murder of a Jewish shopkeeper. While performances by Joe Mantegna and William Macy are strong, the film is marred by an unconvincing and overly theatrical character transformation. The conclusion is clever yet lacks emotional depth, leaving the viewer somewhat disappointed.

This film showcases Jim Carrey in one of his best performances, blending both humor and emotion as he takes on the role of Bruce Nolan, a reporter granted God's powers. Morgan Freeman and Jennifer Aniston provide strong supporting roles, and the mix of comedy and poignant moments adds depth to the story. Overall, it's a well-rounded movie with an engaging plot and a good script.

Movie Review: This review criticizes the movie as a poorly made remake of Bimal Roy's classic *Parineeta*, distorting the original story. It highlights affected acting, out-of-place scenes, and cheap gimmicks, particularly the unnecessary slapping and sex scenes. While the song "Piyu Bole" and a scene where Shekhar stands up to his father are seen as positives, overall, the movie is considered a mishmash that fails to reflect either modern times or stay faithful to the original work.

The reviewer appreciates Timothy Dalton's performance despite thinking he is too young and handsome for the role of Mr. Rochester, while finding Zelah Clarke less fitting. They compare multiple adaptations they've seen of *Jane Eyre*, favoring Orson Welles as Mr. Rochester. The review reflects nostalgia for earlier versions and an enduring appreciation for the novel.

The reviewer expresses significant disappointment with the movie "Bilitis," criticizing its blurry cinematography, incoherent plot, poor acting, cheesy script, and bad pacing. They compare it unfavorably to other films in a similar genre, such as "Emmanuelle" and "Secrets of a Chambermaid," suggesting that even as eye-candy, the movie fails to entertain.

This review acknowledges that some viewers may expect realism but emphasizes that 'SpaceCamp' is a fun, fantasy-driven movie meant for light entertainment. The reviewer fondly recalls enjoying it with both their son and daughter and encourages viewers to embrace the film's fun, imaginative spirit rather than looking for realism in it. It is recommended as a family-friendly movie.

Movie Review: The sequel is regarded as duller and less complex than the original, which had drawn from European influences to present a more ambiguous and subversive take on the American detective genre. While the original "The French Connection" examined the dissolution of the detective figure, the second installment focuses on reasserting traditional Hollywood heroism, following Popeye Doyle’s fall and rise. The film is considered predictable, with an emphasis on Doyle regaining his power, contrasting sharply with the more nuanced and introspective approach of its predecessor.

Movie Review: The reviewer points out two observations about the film, one regarding a potential storytelling inconsistency and the other related to the film's use of time jumps. They found it challenging to follow the plot initially, especially with the shifts in time, but watching the chronological version clarified things. Despite being confused at first, the reviewer seems to appreciate the film's complexity.

The plot takes a backseat to the stunning performances in this film, especially for those interested in French music hall culture. With a standout 10-plus minute cancan finale and lavish Technicolor costumes, it's a visual celebration that serves as Jean Renoir’s affectionate homage to the Paris of his youth. It’s a must-watch for fans of Renoir's lighter works or those with an interest in musical cinema.

The reviewer was captivated by the 1922 silent film, Tess of the Storm Country, and was especially mesmerized by Mary Pickford’s performance. Though initially unfamiliar with silent films and Pickford, the reviewer found themselves thoroughly impressed by her expressive beauty and acting, leaving them eager to begin a collection of her films.

Movie Review: This review criticizes "Superhero Movie" as part of a long line of parody films that have diminished the genre. Despite a decent cast, including Leslie Nielsen and Drake Bell, the humor is seen as predictable and tired, offering very few laughs. While it is considered slightly better than "Meet the Spartans" and "Epic Movie," the reviewer advises avoiding it unless you're a fan of low-quality "car crash cinema."

The reviewer criticizes "Dark Star" (1974) for bad acting, bad writing, and a scientifically nonsensical plot, pointing out the absurdity of the characters and situations, such as a space alien resembling a painted beach ball. They suggest the movie negatively impacted the careers of many involved, calling it one of the worst films they’ve seen.

Fido is a unique and entertaining blend of a Lassie-style family story and a zombie movie, combining a 1950s vibe with a quirky concept. The film follows a boy named Timmy and his pet zombie, Fido, in a world where zombies are controlled through domestication collars. With an all-star cast, sharp writing, and plenty of original, funny moments, Fido is a refreshing addition to the comedy/horror genre and could potentially become a cult classic.

"Pride of the Marines" is an intense and emotionally charged film about a marine, John Garfield, who is blinded during World War II and struggles with his new reality. The movie offers an unflinching portrayal of war's psychological toll, focusing on themes like self-pity, emotional trauma, and the various struggles soldiers face after returning home. Despite a slow beginning, the film evolves into a powerful exploration of heroism, vulnerability, and societal issues, leaving viewers deeply moved.

I thought it was a very funny movie. I love dog movies and comedy movies so combined they were twice as good. Jim Belushi and Jerry Lee make a great comedic team, and the dogs (Jerry Lee and Zeus) were impressively trained, contributing to many hilarious moments. The only downside was some confusion around Dooley's wife's death, but overall it’s a highly enjoyable film with plenty of laughs.

The reviewer strongly dislikes this show, citing poor acting and a contrived storyline. They find the characters and humor unappealing, noting that the original concept, based on insurance commercials, was already overexposed. Overall, they feel that the show's premise falls flat and is not at all entertaining.

movie_metadata.title: Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave
movie_metadata.matched_title: The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave (1971)

reviews.movie: Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave
reviews.review1: The reviewer is highly critical of the movie, calling it a fake and a waste of time. They explain that the film's plot revolves around a convoluted plan where a character named Alan’s relative tries to drive him to suicide to inherit a castle. The reviewer likens the plot to a sloppy Scooby-Doo episode, filled with pointless elements and red herrings, urging others to avoid watching or buying it.

Movie Review: The reviewer criticizes the movie for reusing characters and footage from the previous entries of the Carnosaur series, making it feel lazy and repetitive. They urge others to avoid it, lamenting that Roger Corman's legacy is being tarnished by such films.

Probably one of the funniest so-bad-it's-good movies. The characters take an absurd amount of time realizing what a volcano is, and the rest of the movie involves using implausible methods, like fire trucks, to divert lava through a city. The acting is comically bad, making this an unintentional comedy that leaves viewers in disbelief it was ever made. Worth watching purely for laughs if found cheaply.
